qas.question: Chemicals called neurotransmitters are released at what part of the brain?

answers.text: receptor molecules on the membrane of the synapse's target cell

qas.question: Neurons that release the same chemicals are following what rule?

context: Neurotransmitters are chemicals that are released at <a0_0>synapses<a0_0/> when an action potential activates them—neurotransmitters attach themselves to <a1_0>receptor molecules on the membrane of the synapse's target cell<a1_0/>, and thereby alter the electrical or chemical properties of the receptor molecules. With few exceptions, each neuron in the brain releases the same chemical neurotransmitter, or combination of neurotransmitters, at all the synaptic connections it makes with other neurons; this rule is known as <a2_0>Dale's principle<a2_0/>. Thus, a neuron can be characterized by the neurotransmitters that it releases. The great majority of psychoactive drugs exert their effects by altering specific neurotransmitter systems. This applies to drugs such as cannabinoids, nicotine, heroin, cocaine, alcohol, fluoxetine, chlorpromazine, and many others.
